_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Wynnewood Refining Company (WRC) management follows accidental release and emergency response policies that extend approval authority to levels such that the necessary resources can be immediately committed to provide the manpower, equipment and materials required to expeditiously respond to accidental releases and emergencies.  Prevention policies include a management commitment to make health, safety, and environmental considerations a high priority in planning for all existing and new processes; to operate the refinery in a manner that protects the environment and health and safety of the employees and the community; to resolve problems created by past practices; and to reduce the generation of wastes and releases giving priority to source reduction.  

B.  Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled:

WRC is a petroleum refinery that processes about 54,000 barrels (42-gallons per barrel) of crude oil per day.  The facility refines crude petroleum into a range of petroleum products that include various grades of gasoline; distillates such as keorsene, diesel, and jet fuel; solvents; several types of asphalt; residual fuel oils; and liquefied petroleum gases such as propane, propylene, and butane.  Because of the complexity of the processes and the volume of material processed, the refinery requires a large amount of storage.  WRC has about 80 atmospheric tanks used for storage of various feed stocks, intermediates, chemicals, and products.  Another 27 pressure vessels are used to store high vapor pressure materials such as liquefied petroleum gases.  The total capacity is about 3 million barrels.  The tank sizes vary substantially but the largest atmospheric tank is a 250,000 barrel crude tank and the largest pressure vessel is a 2,400 barrel liquefied petroleum gas tank.

The covered processes considered for the RMP are as follows:

1)  HF Alkyl/Olefin Treater - The HF alky/olefin trea

ter converts olefin and isobutane into gasoline using HF acid as a catalyst.  These units contain about 44,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.  About 90,000 pounds of HF acid is kept in this process.

2)  LPG Rack - This facility is an LPG storage, loading and unloading facility.  The LPG rack contains 24 tanks that typically contain about 3,000,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

3)  Fluid Catalytic Cracker/Gas Con Unit - The FCC/GC unit processes gas oils into LPG?s, gasoline, distillate, and slurry oil.  The FCC/GC unit contains about 87,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

4)  Crude Unit - The crude unit distillation processes crude oil into LPG?s, gasoline, diesel, naphtha, gas oils, and vacuum unit charge.  The crude unit contains about 18,000 lbs of propane, isobutane, butane and pentane.

5)  ROSE Unit - The ROSE unit extracts gas oils from vacuum asphalts using butane as a solvent.  The ROSE unit normally contains about 73,000 lbs of butane.

6)  Isomerization Unit - The isomeration unit converts pentane into isopentane.  This unit contains about 13,500 lbs of pentane and isopentane.

7)  Hydrocracker - The hydrocracker converts LCO and diesel type charge stocks into gasoline and lighter products.  This unit contains about 3,000 lbs of hydrogen, 500 lbs of hydrogen sulfide, and about 65,000 lbs of propane, isobutane, isopentane and heavier hydrocarbons.

8)  Platformer - The platformer converts low octane and straight chain naphtha into high-octane gasoline.  This unit contains about 1,500 lbs of hydrogen, and 15,000 lbs of propane, butane, and heavier hydrocarbons.

9)  Naphtha Unifiner - The naphtha unifiner removes sulfur from the naphtha charge to the platformer.  This unit contains about 1,500 lbs of hydrogen, 100 lbs of hydrogen sulfide, and 25,000 l

bs of pentane and heavier hydrocarbons.

C.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

WRC complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management Program.  Under this program, periodic audits are conducted in all affected units to review and, if necessary, implement changes to improve process safety.  Response to both on-site and off-site emergencies that include accidental releases are managed according to WRC's Integrated Contingency Plan.  This plan, approved by the US EPA, coordinates all emergency response requirements of the various federal programs to include extensive training in the elements of the plan.

Under routine operating procedures, WRC operators visually check their equipment to look for deterioration and signs of leakage.  If a problem is found, the unit undergoes a thorough repair and inspection.  In addition, all process units undergo scheduled shutdown, cleaning and inspection, with repair of any problems found.  Employees, as well as emergency response personnel, including off-site doctors and hospital staffs, have been informed as to what chemicals WRC uses and procedures to minimize effects from exposures.

D.  Five Year Accident History:

During the past five years, this facility has had no releases of any regulated substances that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

E.  Emergency Response Program:

As noted above, WRC uses an integrated contingency plan, as approved by the US EPA, for the emergency responses as required by the various regulations.  Elements of this plan include the incident command structure used to manage the response, procedures for reporting, procedures for coordination with outside emergency responders, and training requirements.  Training includes quarterly notification drills, at least one announced table top drill annually, and at least

one announced deployment drill every three years.

F.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

WRC investigates, thoroughly, all incidents under the OSHA and PSM regulations.  Any recommendations resulting from the investigations are implemented.

In response to Homeland Security, WRC has implemented most of the recommended improvements to increase facility security but continues with additional measures as they are identified for implementation.
